questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements is false about the surgical anatomy of the lungs?

options.a: There are 10 bronchopulmonary segments on the right lung.
options.b: Each bronchopulmonary segment has a separate lymphatic drainage.
options.c: The tracheobronchial tree is normally lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar cells.
options.d: Segmentectomy is done after locating the segmental branch of bronchial artery.

questions.explanation:
In segmentectomy, the segment is removed from the lobe after locating the intersegmental vein. Bronchopulmonary segments are well-defined, anatomic, functional, and surgical areas of the 
lung. There are 10 bronchopulmonary segments each on the right and the left lung. The segments 
help in segmental resection and bronchoscopy as each segment has a separate: • Tertiary bronchus • Segmental artery • Autonomic nerve supply • Lymphatic drainage The tracheobronchial tree is normally lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar cells and 
mucous cells.

questions.question:
Question 2: An infant has a congenital bronchopulmonary malformation as shown in the CT scan given 
below. Which of the following is most likely to supply the marked structure?
questions.explanation:
The given CT shows an intralobar pulmonary sequestration of the left lung. The thoracic 
aorta commonly supplies the sequestered lobe of the lung. Pulmonary sequestration is an area of embryonic lung tissue, separate from the lung. It receives 
blood supply from an anomalous systemic artery from the aorta. It is of two types: • Extralobar sequestration occurs primarily on the left side and blood supply is usually from the 
thoracic or upper abdominal aorta • Intralobar sequestration occurs in the lower lobes predominantly (>95%). It is equally 
distributed between the right and left lower lobe and blood supply is from the descending thoracic 1140 
Sold by @itachibot aorta, venous drainage via pulmonary veins Treatment involves resection of the pulmonary sequestration.

questions.question:
Question 3: 1129 
Sold by @itachibot A 50-year-old patient on DOTS therapy was rushed to the casualty after having massive 
hemoptysis. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.a: Intubation is done into the non-bleeding lung.
options.b: Massive hemoptysis is defined as expectoration of over 750 mL of blood within 24-hours.
options.c: Presence of significant cavitary disease is an indication for urgent surgery.
options.d: Bleeding is most likely due to pulmonary artery erosion.

questions.explanation:
Massive hemoptysis is defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-hour 
period. Common causes include tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, and cancer. It is a medical 
emergency. Any hemoptysis that can cause airway compromise or lead to hemodynamic collapse is called 
massive hemoptysis. This includes blood loss of >600mL/24h or >150ml/h which can flood 
the anatomical dead space of the lung. Bleeding can either be from the bronchial artery circulation (most common) or from the 
pulmonary artery circulation. Bleeding from cavitary lesions is due to pulmonary artery erosion. The chest X-ray is the first investigation followed by rigid or flexible bronchoscopy. The cause of death in massive hemoptysis is usually due to asphyxiation (rather than blood loss 
itself). This is why airway stabilization by intubating into the non-bleeding lung is the priority. 
After ventilation is achieved, the bleeding site should be identified using bronchoscopy. Bleeding 
is controlled by laser, bronchial occlusion, or arterial embolization. Surgical resection of the 
involved area is also done in some cases. Indications for urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis: • Presence of a fungus ball • Presence of a lung abscess • Presence of significant cavitary disease • Failure to control the bleeding.

questions.question: Question 4: Where is Rasmussen’s aneurysm seen?
questions.explanation:
The aneurysm of the pulmonary artery within the tuberculous cavity is called Rasmussen’s 
aneurysm. Rasmussen's aneurysm is an inflammatory pseudo-aneurysmal dilatation. This occurs during the 
healing of the tuberculous cavity. There is a progressive weakening of the arterial wall, in which 
both the tunica adventitia and media are replaced by granulation tissue. This is gradually replaced 
by fibrin resulting in thinning of the arterial wall leading to pseudoaneurysm formation. Rupture of Rasmussen's aneurysm can cause massive hemoptysis. CT angiography plays an 
important role in locating the aneurysm. Most cases of massive hemoptysis arise from the bronchial arterial tree because of high pressure 
within bronchial arteries. Even when a pulmonary aneurysm is present, the actual bleeding may 
be from the bronchial artery, rather than from the pulmonary artery itself. 1141 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 50-year-old chronic smoker with left-sided lung cancer is rushed to the emergency 
department with massive hemoptysis. On examination, pulse - 102 bpm, BP - 80/50 mmHg, 
RR - 30/min. Which of the following will be part of your management plan for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The left side is most likely to be the bleeding side in this patient. Hence, the patient should be 
placed in the left lateral decubitus position to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung. Also, a 
CT scan is not indicated as he is hemodynamically unstable. Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis: • First priorities are to maintain the airway, optimize oxygenation and stabilize the hemodynamic 
status by administering IV fluids. • Chest X-ray is the first investigation of choice. CT scan is done only in hemodynamically stable 
patients. • If the bleeding side is known, the patient should be placed in a lateral decubitus position, with 
the bleeding side down to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung and given supplemental 
oxygen. • If large-volume bleeding continues or the airway is compromised, the patient should be 
intubated and undergo emergency bronchoscopy. • The bleeding site is localized using flexible/rigid bronchoscopy. • Control the hemorrhage: • Endobronchially with Nd: YAG laser or bronchial occlusion • Endovascularly with bronchial and/or pulmonary artery embolization • Electrocauterization • Surgically with resection of the involved lobe The cause of the hemoptysis must be determined to definitively prevent a recurrence.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 54-year-old comes to the casualty with a history of massive hemoptysis. His routine 
investigation and chest X-ray were normal. Which of the following you will not do to prevent 
hemoptysis?
questions.explanation:
Procoagulant drugs are not used to prevent hemoptysis. Procoagulant drugs like vasopressin are 
indicated only if there is an abnormal coagulation profile. Massive hemoptysis is generally defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 
24-h period. Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis: • First priorities are to secure the airway, optimize oxygenation and stabilize the hemodynamic 
status by administering IV fluids. • Chest X-ray is the first investigation of choice. CT scan is done only in hemodynamically stable 
patients. • If the bleeding site is known, the patient should be placed in a lateral decubitus position with the 
bleeding side down to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung. Supplemental oxygen should be 
given. 1142 
Sold by @itachibot • If large-volume bleeding continues or the airway is compromised, the patient should be 
intubated and undergo an emergency bronchoscopy. • The bleeding site is localized using flexible/rigid bronchoscopy. • Control the hemorrhage: • Endobronchially with Nd: YAG laser or bronchial occlusion • Endovascularly with bronchial and/or pulmonary artery embolization • Electrocauterization • Surgically with resection of the involved lobe The cause of the hemoptysis must be determined to definitively prevent a recurrence.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 20-year-old man presents with h/o sudden breathlessness while watching television. Upon 
examination, he is noticed to be 6 ft tall and very lean. He is not breathless at the moment. 
Chest X-ray reveals a right-sided pneumothorax of 1.5 cm. He does not smoke or drink. 
Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary pneumothorax. The next step would be to 
discharge and follow up in 2-4 weeks as the size is <2cm. Pneumothorax is the abnormal accumulation of air in the pleural space. It can be primary or 
secondary. Primary pneumothorax can occur spontaneously due to rupture of the apical blebs. Risk factors 
include: • Males > Females • Young, tall, and thin individuals • Family history • Smoking It resolves spontaneously hence just follow-up is usually needed in most cases. Secondary pneumothorax occurs due to some underlying pathology. Risk factors include: • Age> 50 years • Smoking • COPD • Asthma • Cystic fibrosis • Infection (pneumonia, abscess, and tuberculosis) • Interstitial lung disease • Connective tissue disease • Procedures (subclavian lines, thoracentesis, bronchoscopy, and mechanical ventilation) • Blunt trauma 1143 
Sold by @itachibot Patients with pneumothorax present with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A physical 
examination will reveal: • An enlarged hemithorax • Decreased chest movements • Hyper-resonance on percussion • Absent vocal fremitus • Diminished breath sounds Diagnosis is made by chest X-ray (best initial test), CT scan, or USG. Management of pneumothorax: • Primary pneumothorax • <2 cm size: Discharge and follow-up in 2-4 weeks • >2 cm size and/or breathless: Aspirate with 16 G cannula  If fails, place a chest drain of size 
8-14 Fr • Secondary pneumothorax • <1 cm size: High-flow oxygen with observation for 24 hours • 1-2 cm size: Aspirate with 16 G cannula  If fails, place a chest drain of size 8-14 Fr • >2 cm size: Place chest drain of size 8-14 Fr

questions.question: Question 8: The ultrasound diagnosis of pneumothorax depends on :
questions.explanation:
The ultrasound diagnosis of pneumothorax depends on the presence of barcode sign, absence of 
the sliding lung and absence of comet-tail artifacts that are seen in relation to a normal 
lung–pleural interface. Normally, lung sliding corresponds to the to-and-fro movement of the visceral pleura on the 
parietal pleura that occurs with respiration. It is a dynamic sign and can be identified on 
ultrasound as horizontal movement along the pleural line. In pneumothorax, the air separates visceral and parietal pleura and prevents visualization of 
visceral pleura. Hence lung sliding is absent and typical to and fro movement and shimmering of 
the pleural lines will not be present. Comet tail artifacts are seen in the normal lungs due to the acoustic impedance differences 
between water and air, whereas it is absent in pneumothorax. The image given below shows a sliding sign seen in a normal lung. 1144 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: The quad sign is seen in pleural effusion. It consists of four lines representing the 
pleura, rib, fluid, and lung. Option C: The motionless portion of the chest above the pleural line creates horizontal ‘waves,’ 
and the sliding below the pleural line creates a granular pattern, the ‘sand’. The resultant picture 
is one that resembles waves crashing onto the sand and is therefore called the ‘seashore sign’ and 
is present in normal lungs.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient presents with breathlessness to the casualty after a motorcycle accident. On 
examination, the left chest is hyper-resonant on percussion and shows reduced air entry over 
the same side. His pulse is 110 bpm, RR - 25/min, BP - 80/45mmHg, and JVP was elevated. 
What will be your immediate management?

options.a: Insert a wide bore needle in 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid axillary line
options.c: Insert a chest tube in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The first line of management in 
tension pneumothorax is to insert a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space just anterior to 
the midaxillary line. Pneumothorax is the abnormal accumulation of air in the pleural space. Tension pneumothorax 
develops when air enters the pleural space through a point that acts as a one-way valve. More and 
more air enters with every breath without any way for the air to escape. This is a medical 
emergency where the patient can quickly deteriorate. A patient with pneumothorax presents with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A physical 
examination will reveal: • An enlarged hemithorax • Decreased chest movements • Hyper-resonance on percussion • Absent vocal fremitus • Diminished breath sounds In addition to the above findings, a tension pneumothorax would also have the following: • Deviation of trachea to the opposite side 1145 
Sold by @itachibot • Distended neck vein • Cyanosis • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise: • Hypotension • Tachycardia • Low O2 saturation • Loss of consciousness A diagnosis of tension pneumothorax is usually made based on the clinical findings. If the tension 
in the pleural cavity is not relieved, the patient can die due to hemodynamic collapse. Hence, 
treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation. The management of tension pneumothorax is to convert a tension pneumothorax into a simple 
pneumothorax. This can be done by rapid decompression using a wide-bore cannula on the 
affected side, followed by the insertion of a chest tube for definitive management. The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle (Triangle of safety) that lies: • Anterior to the mid-axillary line • Above the level of the nipple • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle Note: If immediate management is asked, the answer will be to insert a wide-bore needle in the 5th 
intercostal space in the midaxillary line. If definitive management is asked, the answer will be to insert an intercostal tube in the triangle 
of safety. 1146 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a stab wound to his right 
chest following a fight at the local bar. His vitals are normal. On examination, the trachea is 1131 
Sold by @itachibot central and a penetrating wound is noted on the right chest. A sucking sound is heard during 
inspiration. Which of the following is the initial management in this case?

options.a: Occlusive dressing tapped on the 3 sides
options.b: Placing chest drain at the site of the wound

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of open pneumothorax. Initial management, in this case, 
is to apply occlusive dressing taped on the 3 sides. Open pneumothorax is due to a large open defect in the chest, making intrathoracic pressure 
equal to atmospheric pressure. In this defect, the air is preferentially drawn through the defect, 
rather than through the trachea. Air gets accumulated causing pneumothorax leading to 
hypoventilation and hypoxia. It acts as a sucking chest wound. Sucking sound during inspiration 
is characteristic. It is managed initially with the application of a sterile occlusive dressing tapped on the 3 sides. 
Then a chest tube is inserted at a different site, away from the wound.

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient presents with a productive cough, fever, and breathlessness. On examination, 
decreased breath sounds and dull note on percussion is noted on the left side. A chest X-ray is 
given below. USG-guided aspiration revealed frank pus. Chest tube was inserted but there 
was no improvement in symptoms. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of empyema thoracis. Symptoms failed to resolve on 
treatment with chest tube insertion, hence it is managed by VATS debridement. Empyema thoracis is an infection of the pleural space. It commonly progresses from an acute 
phase with thin fluid that can be drained completely with a chest tube or small-bore catheter to a 
more turbid and thick fluid that might loculate. It is an exudative effusion. It can be caused due 
to: • Underlying infection of the lung (pneumonia or abscess) • Complication after chest surgery • Infected hemothorax • Complication of Pleural effusion 1147 
Sold by @itachibot • Trauma (esophageal perforation) • Osteomyelitis of ribs An empyema thoracis on chest x-ray can mimic a pleural effusion or a lung abscess. The procedure VATS (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery) is used in the debridement of 
empyema. At the end of the procedure, chest drains are placed for dependent drainage. If VATS fails to re-expand the lung after drainage, a more radical procedure (decortication) may 
be done.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following is not an indication for performing thoracotomy in patients with blunt 
chest injury? 1132 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: >1500 ml drainage after placing an intercostal tube
options.b: Continuous bleeding through intercostal tube of more than 200 ml/hour for three or more

questions.explanation:
A rib fracture is not an indication for thoracotomy. Indications for thoracotomy: • Initial tube thoracostomy drainage of >1000 ml (penetrating injury) or >1500 ml (blunt 
injury) of frank blood • Ongoing tube thoracostomy drainage of >200 ml/ hr for 3 consecutive hours in 
non-coagulopathic patients with hemothorax • Caked hemothorax despite the placement of two chest tubes • Massive air leak from chest tube with inadequate ventilation • Open pneumothorax • Great vessel injury • Pericardial tamponade • Cardiac herniation • Tracheobronchial injury • Esophageal perforation

questions.question:
Question 13: All of the following will be your differential diagnosis in a patient with anterior mediastinal 
mass except:
questions.explanation:
Neurogenic tumors are found in the posterior mediastinum and not in the anterior mediastinum. They are the most common primary tumors of the posterior mediastinum. Schwannomas and 
Neurilemomas are the most common neurogenic tumors. 1148 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 35-year-old patient complains of double vision that gets worse after he watches television. 
He also has drooping of the eyelids that gets better after a nap. Serology is positive for 
anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. A CT scan of his chest is given below. Which of the 
following is false regarding his condition?

options.a: It is the most common tumor of the anterior mediastinum.
options.b: Masoaka classification system is used for staging.
options.c: Tumor size is a reliable indicator of malignancy.
options.d: Surgery can be performed through a median sternotomy approach.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical features of myasthenia gravis along with the CT scan image showing an anterior 
mediastinal mass are suggestive of thymoma. The only reliable indicator of malignancy in 
thymoma is the capsular invasion, not tumor size. Thymoma is the most common mediastinal tumor and is derived from the thymus gland. 
Thymomas vary in behavior from benign to aggressively invasive. Masoaka classification system is 
used to stage thymomas. Myasthenia gravis is often related to thymomas. Symptoms of myasthenia gravis improve after 
excision of the thymus gland even in the absence of a thymoma. Complete thymectomy is the treatment for thymoma. It can be performed by two approaches: • A median sternotomy approach • A transcervical approach with or without an additional VATS procedure (Video-Assisted 
Thoracoscopic Surgery) for smaller thymomas

questions.question:
Question 15: Which stage of Masaoka staging does a patient with thymoma invading the great vessels come 
under?
questions.explanation:
Thymoma invading great vessels come under stage III of the Masaoka staging system. Masaoka staging system is the most commonly accepted staging system for thymoma. It is based 
on the presence or absence of gross or microscopic invasion of the capsule and of surrounding 
structures, and metastasis. 1149

questions.question:
Question 16: A toddler with cough and progressive breathing difficulty was found to have a poorly defined 
solid mass in the mediastinum. What is the most common mediastinal mass in this age 
group?
questions.explanation:
The most common mediastinal mass in young children is neurogenic tumors (50%-60%). In most 
cases (< 4 years of age), they are invariably malignant. The most common mediastinal masses in adults are thymomas and thymic cysts.

questions.question: Question 17: Lymphomas most commonly a■ect which compartment of the mediastinum?
questions.explanation:
Lymphoma most commonly occurs in the anterior mediastinum. Occasional involvement of the 
middle compartment and rare involvement of posterior mediastinum is seen. Chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy results in a cure rate of up to 90% for early-stage Hodgkin’s 
disease and up to 60% for more advanced stages. Note: • Most common tumor of the middle mediastinum: Lymphoma. • Most common mass of the middle mediastinum: Pericardial Cyst.

questions.question: Question 18: What is the most common benign tumor of the lung?
questions.explanation:
The most common benign tumor of the lung is hamartoma. Hamartoma is a developmental abnormality containing mesothelial and endothelial elements. 
They are manifested by the overgrowth of cartilage. It is typically seen in 40-60 years of age, more 
common in males. It is usually seen in the periphery of the lung and grows slowly. Popcorn calcification in chest 
X-ray is suggestive of a hamartoma. 1150 
Sold by @itachibot Chest X-ray showing a popcorn calcification in the apex of the right lung. Diagnosis and definitive treatment are achieved by excision of the lesion. Gross specimen showing hamartoma of the lung. Note: Popcorn calcification is also seen in: • Chondroid lesions like chondrosarcoma • Fibrous dysplasia • Fibroadenoma breast • Calcified uterine fibroid • Metaphyses and epiphyses of long bones of children with osteogenesis imperfecta 1151 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is true about bronchial carcinoid?
questions.explanation:
Bronchial carcinoid is usually asymptomatic. Bronchial carcinoids are the most indolent of the spectrum of pulmonary neuroendocrine tumors. 
They arise from the Kulchitsky cells in the bronchial epithelium. Most tumors are confined to the 
main stem bronchus and commonly project into the lumen. It is associated with MEN 1. Most patients affected are <40 years and it is not related to smoking. It is usually asymptomatic 
and only 10% of bronchial carcinoids give rise to carcinoid syndrome which is characterized by 
intermittent attacks of: • Diarrhea • Flushing • Bronchospasm • Cyanosis Bronchial carcinoids follow a relatively benign course and do not metastasize to distant sites. They 
have a good prognosis and can be easily resected.

questions.question:
Question 20: In patients with lung cancer, presence of which of the following indicates an 
immune-mediated paraneoplastic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Peripheral neuropathy is an immune-mediated paraneoplastic syndrome. It is due to the secretion 
of antigens normally expressed only by the nervous system which leads to antibodies production 
against CNS. Lung cancers are capable of producing a variety of paraneoplastic syndromes. They may produce 
symptoms even before any local symptoms are produced by the primary tumor, thereby aiding in 
early diagnosis. Paraneoplastic syndromes in lung cancer: System

questions.question:
Question 23: A 52-year-old smoker presents with cough and pain along the right arm for the past few 
weeks. He appears cachexic. On examination, clubbing and right-sided ptosis were noted. 
Chest X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is false about this 
condition?

options.a: CT scan is preferred over MRI.
options.d: N2 nodal stage requires definitive chemoradiotherapy.

questions.explanation:
1155 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario along with the X-ray showing opacity of the apex of the right lung is 
suggestive of Pancoast syndrome. MRI is preferred over CT because of the associated soft tissue 
infiltration, the extent of which can be best visualized using an MRI. Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the 
apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots. Regional spread can cause: • Pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 
2nd ribs • Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis with hoarseness of voice • Endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, 
stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm. • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and 
anhydrosis). It occurs due to invasion of the sympathetic chain and of the inferior cervical 
(stellate) ganglion • Tracheal obstruction • Esophageal compression with dysphagia Bronchoscopy can be done to obtain a tissue diagnosis. Surgery with curative intent is offered to patients with early-stage cancer (T1–3, N0–1). Management is summarized in the flowchart as shown below:

Question 24: During a health checkup in a factory, a 52-year-old worker complained of progressive cough 
and weight loss for the past 6 months. Chest X-ray showed a mass in the right apical region of 
the lung with pleural effusion. The biopsy sample obtained stained positive for calretinin. 
Which of the following is false about this condition?

options.a: Immunohistochemical analysis will be positive for TTF-1.
options.c: Asbestos exposure is the major risk factor.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with biopsy showing positive calretinin is suggestive of mesothelioma. 
The immunohistochemical analysis will be negative for TTF-1 in mesothelioma. TTF-1 is positive 1156 
Sold by @itachibot in adenocarcinoma of the lung. Malignant mesothelioma is the most common tumor of the pleura. Exposure to asbestos is the 
major known risk factor. The latency period between asbestos exposure and the development of 
mesothelioma is at least 20 years. It is more common in males, usually seen after 40 years of age. 
It has a very poor prognosis. Histological subtypes include: • Epithelial • Sarcomatous • Biphasic The physical characteristics of specific fibers are important for causation. They are: • Serpentine fibers: Large and curly, not able to travel beyond larger airways. • Amphibole fibers: The narrow, straight amphibole fibers, in particular, the crocidolite fibers 
navigate distally into the pulmonary parenchyma and are most clearly associated with 
mesotheliomas. It is not bilaterally symmetrical. Its clinical features include: • Dyspnoea • Chest pain • Pleural effusion – in 90% cases Diagnostic imaging includes chest X-ray, CT scan, and FDG-PET scan to determine the extent of 
tumor invasion and to evaluate occult metastases. Thoracoscopy or open pleural biopsy with 
special staining of tumor samples is required to differentiate mesotheliomas from 
adenocarcinomas. Treatment includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Extrapleural 
pneumonectomy and total pleurectomy are two commonly used surgical procedures. 1157

questions.question:
Question 25: A 48-year-old man with a chronic history of smoking is diagnosed with small cell lung 
carcinoma. Which of the following statement is false regarding the management of the 
patient?

options.b: In wedge resection, anatomical bronchopulmonary segment is removed.
options.c: Posterolateral thoracotomy approach is used for surgical resection.
options.d: Lobectomy is the treatment of choice for early-stage lung cancer.

questions.explanation:
Wedge resection involves the non-anatomical excision of the tumor. Excision of the anatomical 
bronchopulmonary segment is called segmentectomy. Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a type of tumor that originates from neuroendocrine progenitor 
cells (Kulchitsky cells) in the lining bronchial epithelium. They tend to metastasize early to lymph 
nodes and by the blood-borne spread. SCLC is very responsive to chemotherapy such that median survival may be doubled. Surgery for lung cancers: Surgery with curative intent is offered to patients with early-stage lung cancer (T1–3, N0–1). Lung 
cancer resection can be approached through: • Posterolateral thoracotomy • Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) Complications of surgery include: • Bleeding • Respiratory infection • Persistent air-leak • Bronchopleural fistula

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore?
questions.explanation:
The complication of surgery is not a component of thoracoscore. Thoracoscore is used to assess the risk of operative mortality in a patient undergoing thoracic 
surgery. It includes 9 variables: 1158

questions.question:
Question 27: A patient with a mediastinal mass undergoes the following procedure. Which of the following 
statements is false? 1137 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: The patient is positioned in a lateral decubitus with the diseased side up.
options.b: It is contraindicated if the patient is having empyema.
options.c: Lobectomy can be done via this procedure.
options.d: It allows direct visualization of the pleural cavity.

questions.explanation:
The procedure that is shown is Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) and empyema is not 
a contraindication for the procedure. VATS is a minimally invasive surgical technique used to diagnose and treat disorders of the 
thoracic cavity. It also allows direct visualization of the pleural cavity. Lung biopsy and recurrent pneumothorax are the most frequent indications for VATS. Other 
conditions where VATS is used include: • Malignancies • Empyema • Oesophageal surgeries • Patent ductus areteriosus • Undiagnosed pleural effusion • Pneumonectomy • Lobectomy • Pleural biopsy • Pleurodesis The patient is usually positioned with the diseased side up in a lateral decubitus position. 
A double lumen endotracheal-bronchial tube is placed by the anesthetist for single-lung 
ventilation. At the end of the procedure, chest drains are placed to allow dependent drainage. The following precautions must be noted before placing the drains: • The drain should exit the skin anterior to the midaxillary line. If this is not done then the patient 
will have to lie on the tube which will cause pain and obstruction of the tube. • The course of the drain should be oblique to the skin, chest wall, and pleura, or else it will lead 
to kinking of the tube. 1159 
Sold by @itachibot The main advantage of VATS is that a large incision is avoided. This causes less postoperative pain 
and a rapid recovery. However, VATS procedure limits the ability of the surgeon to palpate the 
lung to identify occult metastases.

questions.question: Question 28: What is the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending artery while performing CABG?
questions.explanation:
The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery is the conduit of choice for 
the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The most important criterion in conduit 
selection is graft patency. The conduit with the highest patency rate is the left internal mammary 
artery or internal thoracic artery. Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery > long saphenous vein represents the correct 
order of graft patency in a patient undergoing CABG procedure. Venous grafts: • The long saphenous vein is the most common vein used as a conduit as it is straightforward to 
harvest, provides good length, and is easy to handle. • The ten-year patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts is reported to be 50–60 percent. Arterial grafts: • The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery has become the conduit of 
choice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The radial artery can be used as a 
second or alternative arterial bypass graft. Other arterial bypass grafts include the gastroepiploic 
artery and the inferior epigastric artery. • Long patency rates of >98 percent have been reported.

questions.question:
Question 29: A 55-year-old man has been in the ICU for the past 1 month due to end-stage liver failure. He 
is not eligible for a transplant and his doctors have said there is nothing they can do at this 
stage. His family has consented to organ donation once his heart stops. Which of the 
categories of non-beating heart donors would this patient fall into as per the modified 
Maastricht classification?

options.a: Pain is usually felt in the calf muscles
options.b: Muscle group affected is below the level of arterial disease
options.c: Distance at which pain occurs varies greatly from day to day
options.d: Worsened by anemia or heart failure

questions.explanation:
The patient would fall under category III. Modified Maastricht classification- Categories of non-heart-beating donors: • Uncontrolled - transplant team not present or prepared • Category I - includes victims of accident and suicide who are found dead at the scene and 
resuscitation is deemed pointless (e.g. fatal cervical spine fracture). • Category II - donors are mostly victims of sudden cardiac or cerebral catastrophes who are 
brought to emergency departments while being resuscitated by ambulance personnel or who die 
in the department. Other sources include patients suffering an isolated brain injury, anoxia, and 
stroke, and victims of major trauma who died soon after hospital admission. • Category V - Unexpected cardiac arrest during intensive care. • Controlled - transplant team present and prepared • Category III - encompasses patients who are dying, often in an intensive care unit. These are the 
patients awaiting cardiac arrest where the treating clinicians have decided to withdraw treatment 
and not commence resuscitation for various reasons. 1160 
Sold by @itachibot • Category IV - comprises patients who suffer unexpected cardiac arrest during or after the 
determination of brain death. 1161
